Hi Paul,

As you've already pointed out it could make a difference that you=
're not
using NEAT. We believe that NEAT is beneficial to Novelty Search be=
cause it
gradually complexifies behaviors which reduces the novelty search =
space.
Your novelty metric seems similar to the one I used so I think that
=
shouldn't make a big difference.

Were you able to evolve learning behavior=
 with a regular fitness function?
What kind of adaptation mechanism are you=
 using?

Cheers,
Sebastian


On Fri, Dec 4, 2009 at 12:50 PM, Nemo 136 <nem=
o136@...> wrote:

>
>
> Hello,
>
> I'm currently trying to reproduce =
the results in
> http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2009/risi.gecco09.htm=
l and finding
> out if a NEAT algorithm is necessary to obtain theses resul=
ts. Right now, I
> manage without too many problems to get behaviors changi=
ng depending on the
> trial / deploy.
>
>  Though, the novelty keeps trying=
 new behaviors based upon crashing / not
> crashing or getting one reward o=
r not getting it, and returning or not
> returning to the origin (no reward=
). This fills up the archive quite fast
> without any actual "learning" app=
earing (the best scores show 60% to 70% of
> all high reward reached withou=
t any clear "learning" pattern).
>
> I would like to know if some code is p=
rovided online for this experiment,
> or if you could send me the code used=
 in this experiment, if only to try to
> see which parameters are different=
 in the two of them, so that I can try to
> pinpoint the differences.
>
> R=
ight now, the differences I can see are :
> - simple network evolution algo=
rithm vs NEAT mechanisms
> - possible difference in the way of counting for=
 novelty score : I am using
> a bitset of size 4*nb_deploy*nb_trials with e=
ach bit standing for : a crash,
> a high reward, a low reward, returning to=
 the starting point wit the reward.
> I do a hamming distance between behav=
iors to get my novelty score. But, it
> seems to be the same mechanisms as =
in the paper
> - generation based algorithm while the paper uses a a steady=
 state approach
> in which only one individual is generated at each generat=
ion
>
> Cheers.
>
> Paul Tonelli
>
>
>  
>

Hi Paul,<br><br>As you've already pointed out it could make a differenc=
e that you're not using NEAT. We believe that NEAT is beneficial to Nov=
elty Search because it gradually complexifies behaviors which reduces the n=
ovelty search space. Your novelty metric seems similar to the one I used so=
 I think that shouldn't make a big difference.<br>
<br>Were you able to=
 evolve learning behavior with a regular fitness function? What kind of ada=
ptation mechanism are you using? <br><br>Cheers,<br>Sebastian<br><br><br><d=

Hello, <br><br>I'm currently trying to reproduc=
e the results in <a href=3D"http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2009/risi.=
gecco09.html" target=3D"_blank">http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2009/r=
isi.gecco09.html</a> and finding out if a NEAT algorithm is necessary to ob=
tain theses results. Right now, I manage without too many problems to get b=
ehaviors changing depending on the trial / deploy.<br>


<br>=C2=A0Though, =
the novelty keeps trying new behaviors based upon crashing / not crashing o=
r getting one reward or not getting it, and returning or not returning to t=
he origin (no reward). This fills up the archive quite fast without any act=
ual "learning" appearing (the best scores show 60% to 70% of all =
high reward reached without any clear "learning" pattern).<br>


=
<br>I would like to know if some code is provided online for this experimen=
t, or if you could send me the code used in this experiment, if only to try=
 to see which parameters are different in the two of them, so that I can tr=
y to pinpoint the differences. <br>


<br>Right now, the differences I can =
see are :<br>- simple network evolution algorithm vs NEAT mechanisms<br>- p=
ossible difference in the way of counting for novelty score : I am using a =
bitset of size 4*nb_deploy*nb_trials with each bit standing for : a crash, =
a high reward, a low reward, returning to the starting point wit the reward=
. I do a hamming distance between behaviors to get my novelty score. But, i=
t seems to be the same mechanisms as in the paper<br>


- generation based =
algorithm while the paper uses a a steady state approach in
which only one =
individual is generated at each generation<br><br>Cheers.<br><br>Paul Tonel=
li<br><br>
